title: Living By The Sword
summary:
Key ideas:
- A man known for his activism in the feminist movement, Charles Clymer, became the center of negative attention on Twitter after his views on religion and feminism were deemed inappropriate.
- Due to past disagreements and interactions with women, he was accused of being a misogynist and a predator by some people on Twitter.
- The author of the blog post questions the fairness and proportionality of the accusations targeted at Clymer and expresses sympathy for him despite earlier criticism.
- Whales have evolved to not suffer from cancer even though they have many more cells than humans.
- One proposed theory is that whale cancers also develop cancer and die off.
- Cooperation enforcement mechanisms in cancerous cells are much worse than non-cancerous cells’ cooperation mechanisms.
- A definition for “social cancer” might be any group that breaks the rules of cooperative behavior that bind society together to spread more quickly than it could legitimately achieve

Key learnings:
- Social media can easily fuel a mob mentality that leads to oversimplification, demonization, and harassment of individuals who are deemed to have transgressed the boundaries of politically correct conduct.
- Allegations of misogyny and sexual abuse can quickly spiral out of control, causing psychological harm to the accused as well as others who are caught in the crossfire.
- Civility and objectivity are crucial principles in any discussion, even when discussing sensitive topics such as rape, feminism, and religion.
- The reason for whales not suffering from cancer is still unclear.
- Cooperation enforcement mechanisms in non-cancerous cells are much better than cancerous ones.

Key questions:
- How can we create a culture that promotes reasoned debate and respectful disagreement without triggering abusive behavior and polarizing factions?
- How should we deal with cases where people who have been accused of wrongdoings refuse to acknowledge their mistakes or apologize for their actions?
- To what extent should people be held accountable for their past words or deeds, especially if they have already expressed remorse or changed their views?
- What is the reason for whales not suffering from cancer?
- What other proposed solutions are there for Peto's paradox?
- What is the definition of a “social cancer”?
